definitions.text: To hold or keep something physically in one's hands or possession
To keep, maintain, or continue a state or condition
To operate or run (a business or establishment)

examples.french: Je tiens un livre dans ma main.
examples.english: I am holding a book in my hand.

examples.french: Tiens-moi la porte, s'il te plaît.
examples.english: Hold the door for me, please.

examples.french: Ils tiennent un petit restaurant au centre-ville.
examples.english: They run a small restaurant downtown.
examples.note: Meaning shifts to operating an establishment

examples.french: Ce projet tient grâce à ton organisation.
examples.english: This project holds together thanks to your organization.

grammar: Irregular verb of the -tenir group (tenir, venir, retenir, etc.)
Conjugated with the auxiliary 'avoir' in compound tenses (j'ai tenu)
Imperative forms are irregular: tiens, tenons, tenez
collocations: tenir à quelqu'un (to care about someone)
tenir compte de (to take into account)

idioms.meaning: to endure; to hold up under pressure
to be solid, reliable, or make sense

etymology.evolution: Latin "tenēre" (to hold) → Vulgar Latin "tenēre" → Old French "tenir" → Modern French "tenir"
etymology.note: Shares root with English 'tenacious' and 'tenant'; semantic field relates to possession and stability

frequency_note: High-frequency verb appearing across everyday speech, literature, and formal writing.
usage_notes: Tenir is extremely common and flexible, with both literal and figurative meanings. Mastery of its idiomatic forms (tenir à, tenir compte de) is essential for authentic intermediate-level expression. The -tenir family of verbs requires memorization due to irregular stems.
social_hook: This verb is everywhere in French, from holding objects to keeping promises—do you already use it?
